From the Economist
“Shifting ground: Pelosi backs impeachment	 
Nancy Pelosi, the House Speaker, has announced that the House of Representatives will begin an impeachment inquiry into President Donald Trump—something she had long resisted. It comes after the Director of National Intelligence refused to turn over a whistleblower’s complaint to Congress, which Democrats argue is unlawful. Though nobody has yet seen the complaint, it appears to concern Mr Trump allegedly putting pressure on Volodymyr Zelensky, Ukraine’s president, to open an investigation into Hunter Biden, the son of his leading Democratic rival, by withholding military aid. Mr Trump contends that he has done nothing unlawful. He vowed to release a transcript of a phone call with Mr Zelensky. That won’t mollify Democrats, who wish to see the entire complaint. The DNI will testify before the House tomorrow. Mr Trump should not take Republican support for granted. Just before Ms Pelosi spoke, the Senate voted unanimously for the complaint to be passed to its intelligence committee.”

Despite recent Developments following the Ukraine phone call, the likelihood that impeachment proceedings will be sped up to the extent that they are officially by the House of Representatives passed in under a week is exceedingly low.

Democrats will only be able to bring impeachment proceedings and pass them if public support increases significantly. It's hard to see how anything that Trump would do at this stage would shock the nation enough for public opinion to push Democrats as a group towards impeachment.  While he has done many things that would have prompted impeachment proceedings for less bombastic, erratic, and ignorant leaders, Americans as a whole are ossified in their opinions. Many people who supported him will continue to do so no matter what he does, either because they support his crueler policies such as immigrant detention, or because they perceive benefit in his stacking of the courts with conservative judges that outweighs whatever they dislike. The people who oppose Trump will not change their minds but they are not growing in number and influence, nor do all of them see a need for impeachment proceedings. There are people who don't have enough interest or awareness of world and national events to care, and tend to view their lack of opinion as intellectually superior to support or opposition. They won't be reached in large numbers unless something drastic brings change to their personal lives and they can correctly recognize it as being a result of Trump's actions.  The most likely group to change their minds are former Trump supporters who are suffering economically due to Trump's trade war with China (particularly truckers and farmers) who may feel betrayed. However, there's a good chance of them not reassessing or changing their support due to the sunk cost fallacy and the fact that they've been indoctrinated into a worldview where liberalism and even other Republicans are untrustworthy and un-American. I think that some will vociferously support candidates who oppose Trump, but on the whole, it seems more likely that this group will feel jaded and merely withdraw from politics. I am also from rural America, and there is very much an attitude of resentment towards the perceived conventional political class which is dismissive and ignorant of problems in rural America, as well as a feeling of moral and cultural superiority based in large part on self-defining as a region in opposition to the perceived 'other' of people in more densely populated areas, whose lifestyles and problems rural America is as dismissive of as urban America is dismissive of rural America's problems. The media diet in rural America is also extremely right-wing and in the last decade or so has taken a sharp turn that way. Without exposure to other viewpoints except through the demonization and maliciously mocking misrepresentation in extreme right-wing media, people living in rural America have been lead to believe that they alone are seeing with clarity and have no good-faith interaction with other viewpoints.  I only give this possibility any points at all because there have been increasing stories of economic suffering in the communities that Trump pandered to for votes, which some of them correctly attribute to his trade policies and are angry about. (For example, the promised tax cuts have actually drastically increased the taxes that truckers must pay, because they no longer receive per diem budget for eating and other expenses while working. This presents immediate financial harm to this group, which might spur more of them to outright oppose Trump and his supporters as being in opposition to their best interests.)  However, it is likely that this narrative in the media is not reflective of the overall trend of public opinion in the group, because most people are unwilling to admit having been wrong about something they were passionate about for years.

Base case - 4 out of 44 presidents (before trump) faced impeachment process. There has been 2760 months (230 years) since Washington became president, and so there have been 4 instances over 230 years, which is a base case of 4/2760 (.00144) for any given month for a president to face impeachment, but a 4 out of 44 odds that they would face impeachment sometime during their presidency. I have started with a base rate of 2 out of 44 presidents who have had an article of impeachment passed against them in the House of Representatives. (There is a case for making the denominator the number of terms, as opposed to the number of presidents.) My forecast tries to condition the forecast with the specifics of Trump's presidency - which i intuit to be materially different to the "average" presidency. There are already formal proceedings underway, including court filings and committee investigations, that are aimed at providing Democrats with legal/constitutional backing to initiate an articles of impeachment. There is a strong likelihood they will have firm legal grounds to go ahead with a vote.  If it does go to a vote, the Democrats have sufficient partisan votes (235) to get the needed simple majority votes of 218 to get the articles of impeachment passed in the House of Representatives. 119 representatives out of 215 respondents have already publicly declared support for an impeachment. However, they will do so knowing that they will struggle to get him impeached by getting the two-thirds majority needed in a senate that is Republican controlled, and to do so before his term ends. So what do the Democrats have to gain and what do they stand to lose from passing the article and failing to remove as president?

But the House did not directly vote on whether Trump should be impeached. The vote was instead about whether Green’s impeachment resolution should be set aside (“tabled”), as leaders of both parties wanted. A “yea” vote meant shelving impeachment for now (though not necessarily forever). A “no” vote would have meant keeping Green’s resolution on the House floor and proceeding to an actual vote on impeaching Trump. As expected, though, Republicans and most Democrats came together to vote “yes,” tabling the measure, 332-95. The overall split in the Democratic Party: 137 voted to table and 95 voted against doing so.

There is a disturbing, or at least disheartening, tendency here and elsewhere to suppose that the decision to impeach a US president in this or any other case is determined mostly by the preponderance of evidence, real or imagined.  This decision has always been and always will be (and in my opinion for what it's worth, should be) a cold, hard political calculation by the Speaker and the Speaker's closest advisors. It is true that they will take notice of  such evidence as been made available, but this always has been and always will be weighed against other factors, including but definitely not limited to the preferences of caucus members, the strength of the opposition, such public opinion as can be divined, and the imminence and expected closeness of Congressional and presidential elections.  Sometimes the press of other legislative business even worms its way onto the list, and very occasionally the expected money cost of the House and Senate proceedings does so, but how those are weighted in the decision is also a political calculation.   I feel compelled to point out that I almost never use "political" as a pejorative, and am not doing so in this case.  It is a legitimate set of criteria, always considered and sometimes but not always predominating over "economic," "social," "ideological" (also not pejorative) and other criterion sets. However, this Speaker, like almost all her predecessors, does not confide in me, so there is an excellent chance I am wrong about what she'll decide.

Representative Green’s attempt to introduce articles impeachment was beat back handedly. The 332-to-95 vote to table the impeachment article drafted by Representative Al Green, Democrat of Texas, constituted the first action by the House since Democrats took control in January on a measure to impeach Mr. Trump, a significant move that Speaker Nancy Pelosi of California and other party leaders have toiled to avoid. By agreeing to table the article, Ms. Pelosi and the Democrats put off — at least for now — a prolonged and divisive debate over whether Mr. Trump’s conduct warrants his expulsion.
But it was hardly the last word on the topic from Democrats torn about how to deal with the president, between progressives who want to challenge him more aggressively and moderates desperate to quash talk of impeachment and stick to a poll-tested agenda that includes improving health coverage and raising wages for working people. Impeachment resolution fails, but reveals extent of Democratic split

The Democratic leadership has a very clear strategy of not supporting impeachment for a number of reasons: the process itself, their understanding of delivering what the people want, and their long-term strategy.  Firstly, it's an extremely laborious process. Because the elections are coming, the Democrat campaign would have to be focused on impeachment, which would take a very long time - if started now, it would probably take about a year, which is well into the campaign. (For instance, Nixon's impeachment took 10 months, from October 1973 until Augst 974). The energy and resources which are required to impeach would create a gap in the campaigning efforts that will be due at that point. It would make a negative campaign, rather than a constructive approach which is probably what the US wants. Secondly, the Democrats understand that the process would divide the country further. It would give Trump the chance to be seen as a victim, again as an outsider - much like his strategy in 2016. It would confirm that he is anti-establishment - and therefore, that the ones who remove him are the establishment, all that which the Clintons represented and was despised enough to allow Trump to win. Nancy Pelosi recognised this in her statement: "Trump is goading us to impeach him. Every single day, he's just like taunting, taunting, taunting because he knows that it would be very divisive in the country, but he doesn't really care. He just wants to solidify his base."  Thirdly, an impeachment would make Mike Pence resdent. Not only do they not like him, but in this scenario, he would have the power to pardon Trump, which is probably the worst outcome, given the account of the crimes he has committed.  Rather than having him impeached, the Democrats want to see him behind the bars, as Pelosi declared 2 days ago: “I don’t want to see him impeached,” Pelosi said to her Democratic colleagues. “I want to see him in prison.” At the moment, Pelosi is very powerful, and is against it and vehemently so. This judgement is explained by Jewel Hill: "Impeachment is like putting a child in time out; imprisonment is like putting a child on punishment and taking away their video games, toys and outside privileges. A child learns more from being without nothing for a long time, rather than being in a corner and with everything for a short time."  Therefore, I forecast that as things are, there will not be an impeachment. The reason why I still forecasted a 10% chance, more than my peers, is because there is still one case scenario that might alter the picture. If Trump was to do something with huge consequences, such as invading Venezuela as an example, then that could shift the Republicans. It is only in a situation of bipartisan support that the Democrats would pursue an impeachment, because it would essentially mean that that is what the country wants. There could also be a theoretical shift among the Democrats that would start putting pressure on leadership for impeachment - hence my 10%.  https://ncatregister.com/15726/the-word/trump-should-be-imprisoned-not-just-impeached/
https://edition.cnn.com/2019/05/07/politics/pelosi-impeachment-trump-congress/index.html

" It takes a vote of “two-thirds of the Members present” in the Senate to convict any federal officer subject to an impeachment charge, including the president." The two-thirds vote to convict means that 67 votes are needed in the 100-member Senate to remove the president and other federal officers from office. That is a very high hurdle that’s probably impossible to leap over in the case of Trump. Democrats and independents allied with them hold only 47 seats in the Senate—meaning that even if they all voted to convict Trump, they would also need the votes of 20 Republican senators.

There are several reasons as for why I believe an impeachment against President Trump will not take place before 01st October 2019. In the history of the United States only 2 Presidents have been successfully impeached, 1868 and PResident Clinton in 1998 on the basis of a sexual harrassement sue. 
Article 1 & 2 of the constitution line out the grounds of a possible impeachment to be "treason, bribery, or other high crimes and misdemeanors" and a simple majority in the House of Representatives is needed to pass an article of impeachment.  According to an estimation by CBS News (https://www.cbsnews.com/news/trump-impeachment-tracker-how-many-democrats-are-calling-for-an-impeachment-inquiry-into-president-trump/) 57 Democrats and one Republican are in favour of impeachment (status June 4th 2019). However, for a simple majority 218 votes would be needed, making it next to all the Democrat votes also 25 of the Republicans. The numbers, yet show not a trend towards impeachment. Furthermore, speaker of the House Pelosi (Democrat) is stating that she is rather in favour of investigation once Trump will, eventually, have lost re-election in 2020, rather than impeachment now - she is backed by many Democrats on that (https://www.npr.org/2019/06/08/730697885/poll-support-for-impeachment-hearings-grows-but-americans-split-on-way-forward).  Lastly, as mentioned impeachment can happen on grounds of "treason, bribery, or other high crimes and misdemeanors" which is hence still up to interpretation if the alleged claimes the Mueller report makes would provide ground for 'high crimes or misdemeanors' (https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2019/06/05/opinion/impeachment-trump-democrats-nixon-clinton.html).

Update:  As I've mentioned before, the Mueller report carried significant risks for Trump's presidency. During the first hearing today the US Special Counsel Robert Muller said that charging Trump with a crime is not an option. Even though he doesn't exclude the possibility of Trump committing a crime, he claims that "the Constitution requires a process other than the criminal justice system to formally accuse a sitting president of wrongdoing".  Mueller has also decided to "return to private life" and resign from the justice department.  Even though Mueller indicated that it’s up to Congress to decide what happens next, the leaders of Democratic party are still hesitant and encourage others to stay patient. Senator Cory Booker - a Democratic candidate for the next Presidential elections - claims that no one should be above the law and the impeachment  proceedings must begin. I am new to this and just an average coffee drinker/paper reader, and this is my first forecast.  I have read many of the posts and will ping mostly off SRM-Nostradamus who's forecast analysis narrative was rather in-depth.   I agree that there is no precedence in American history for a successful bid to impeach a sitting President.  There is also a growing polarization within politics unlike anything I have seen in 50 years.  The calls for impeachment over the past two years have come with numerous rationalizations up to and including invoking the 25th Amendment - calling Trump mentally incapable.  This alone gives the impression of political rhetoric designed to whip up the frenzy of the opposing political party.  There was much anticipation that the Muller report would be the smoking gun needed to garner more wide-spread/main stream support for impeachment proceedings.  Both sides of the political aisle have claimed a victory in the released Mueller report, but nothing in the report or anything reported in the news (CNN, MSNBC, FOX, NYT, Wash Post) has lead me to believe there is enough evidence to conclude Trump colluded in anyway.  There is also not enough information to support a conclusion that he obstructed the investigation, though there are hints and innuendo.  However, hints and innuendo are insufficient to persuade a Grand Jury to indict.   The recurring calls for Trump's impeachment now appear to be nothing more than the political bantering of candidates and representatives who want to continue to appeal to the emotions of their fringe voters during the primary season.  The seasoned members of the party seem to be weighing this and realize this is actually a political hot potato.  Trump has high approval ratings in many polling districts, has wide appeal to the rust belt and fly-over states, has produced economically beneficial activities that have helped the minority communities - who now show greater support for Trump than any other Republican President in modern history.  These are historically Democratic voters that the Democratic party will need to court in the 2020 election.  Impeachment proceedings may have a very big boomerang effect with them.  This has the appearance of the fringe elements of the Democratic left being the drunk little guy in the bar at the end of the night picking fights he knows he won't get in because his bigger tougher friend will save him from himself.   There is also the issue of the rebound effect - the same reason the Democrats did not use the "nuclear option" several years ago as they knew it would set a new precedence and could open the door to the opposing party using that option in the future.   I also see the Attorney General's investigating the origins of the Page Dossier, and the tactics of the Mueller investigation as a sign that upon further independent review there was politically motivated impropriety, giving greater weight to the notion that no evidence whatever exists to support criminal charges or impeachment for anything - making an attempt to do so look like a kangaroo court.   All this leads me to believe that there is less than a 10% chance that the Democratic party will initiate impeachment proceedings.  However, there are a large number of young, politically inexperienced, idealistic freshmen congressmen who, without the benefit of political savvy and connective thinking could pressure the party at large to initiate proceedings - much the same way they have been pressuring many of the presidential candidates in their party to apologize for decades old slights.
I think they are too immobilised on this. To late to do it. Too risky.

In the history of the US there have been only two cases in which a filed article of impeachment against the president were successful in the House of Representatives: Andrew Johnson in 1868 and William J. Clinton in 1999. In both cases, the Senate disapproved the filed articles of impeachment and acquitted the accused presidents. Andrew Johnson remained in the parliament because 7 republican senators decided to reject the impeachment proposal by their party. They were convinced that the impeachment of Andrew Johnson was political motivated rather than based on constitutional concerns. The Clinton impeachment failed for similar reasons. Some republican senators who, despite condemning the president’s behaviour, opposed to impeach the president as they didn’t assess Clinton’s behaviour as unconstitutional. These developments show that there is a nonpartisan consensus that a president shouldn’t be impeached for political motivated reasons. This is relevant for this forecast as it demonstrates that Trump doesn’t face a risk to be forced out of office due to his unpopularity among US citizens and policy-makers. There are two decisive factors which influence the probability that a filed article of impeachment will be successful in the House of Representatives:  A) Majority within the House of Representative willing to impeach president? 
-> The Democratic Party currently holds the majority in the House of Representatives with 235 seats against 199 Republican seats. This means, that the party could impeach Donald Trump if 218/235 of its members support an impeachment. Nevertheless, there aren’t enough members in the Democratic party who support an impeachment of president Trump so far. The House Majority Leader Steny Hoyer and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi have rejected to file for an article of impeachment in the recent years. The former one stresses that the next presidential election will take place in 18 months anyway. Indeed, a factor which reduces the likelihood over time that anti-impeachment Democrats will change their mind till the end of the term. Another aspect is that an impeachment procedure would need to pass the Senate which is majority-owned by the Republican party. As a result, the risk to see an article of impeachment fail in the Senate might be too high to motivate sceptical Democrats in the House to vote for an impeachment. Furthermore, these Democrats are also concerned that Trump could successfully instrumentalize a failed impeachment attempt for his re-election campaign. However, there is a factor which might increase the likelihood for them to change their minds: the full disclosure of an unedited Mueller report which proves that the president behaved unconstitutional.  -> Justin Amash is the first Republican congress member who supports the impeachment of Donald Trump. He has changed his mind after he read the Mueller report (see below) and concluded that the president “engaged in specific actions [that] meet the threshold for impeachment” (requoted from BBC; addition in [] made by BBC). He also claims that only a few congress members read the report but that a majority base their support/opposition for an impeachment solely on “partisan affiliation”. Indeed, the Republican party faces criticism for supporting Trump without reserve despite some moral questionable activities done by the president. This support seems to be too strong for a significant amount of Republican congress members voting for an impeachment against the president.  B) Possible future inquiries that increase/decrease the likelihood of an impeachment? 
-> The most important inquiry which could create a momentum against Donald Trump would be the publication of evidences for a collusion between the US president and Russia to influence the US election or proof that Trump intentionally tried to obstruct justice. For this purpose, the FBI conducted an investigation which resulted in the so-called “Mueller report”. The report was initially summed up and presented by Attorney General William Barr. The Democratic party accuses the Attorney General of deliberate misrepresentation to reduce the importance of the findings and protect the president of an impeachment. The report “found no criminal conspiracy between Trump’s 2016 election campaign and Russia. However, it did find 10 instances where Mr Trump possibly attempted to impede the investigation” (quote BBC). Nonetheless, so far there is no unredacted version of the report and Barr successfully refuses to publish one. Furthermore, the Attorney General initiated an investigation to examine if the FBI obeyed to US law while they had been investigating on a possible collusion. This means that it is less likely that any decisive events (such as a reveal of an unredacted version) will happen before the 1st of October 2019.  Another reference case to consider would be the one of Nixon. While not being technically impeached, the House Judiciary Committee proposed three articles of impeachment for the congress to consider. Nixon left the office before the congress could make a decision. Nonetheless, trying to forecast if Donald Trump would resign as US president due to the pressure of an impeachment procedure is difficult as it depends on various important variables/aspects which are completely unknown at the time of this forecast (e.g.: did the president conduct criminal activities?). So far, Donal Trump claims that he isn’t concerned of an impeachment. Therefore, this forecast assumes that Donald Trump wouldn’t step down if he faces an impeachment.   To conclude, there are only two cases where the House of Representative passed an article for impeachment and in both cases the Senate failed the attempts based on concerns that they are only political motivated. Although the Democratic party has a majority in the House and could pass an impeachment proposal it seems very unlikely that all Democratic congress members would support this move. On the other hand, there aren’t enough Republican congress members who could substitute this loss and it also seems very unlikely that this will change soon. The only real ‘game changer’ is a full disclosure of the Muller report which provides enough momentum to carry an article of impeachment through both chambers of the congress. However, this seems unlikely itself (regarding the lack of evidence for a collusion) and it is also very unlikely to take place before the 1st of October as the Attorney General successfully delayed disclosure so far and started new investigations which might undermine the Mueller report in the first place. The remaining probability relies on the possibility that the Mueller report will be released soon and that it contains enough evidence for an article of impeachment based on obstruction of justice. In a series of tweets Republican Rep. Justin Amash condemned President Trump’s actions in light of the Mueller Report, saying that Trump had "engaged in impeachable conduct". This makes Amash the first republican to publicly linking Trump to a potential impeachment process. It is significant to see such serious criticism from within the ranks of the republican party, although the congress member has been an open critic of Trump in the past. Adding to this, Sen. Mitt  Romney called Amash’ announcement a “courageous statement”, though he expressed that he did not find impeachment to be the proper course of action. While these statements to not immediately influence the current impeachment talks and push for the process to be initiated, they do potentially open for a broader debate about impeachment – outside of the super vocal group of democrats that have been pushing for it for a long time. Similarly, Amash and Romney’s willingness to speak about this could bring a sense of legitimacy to these talks for Republican voters and thereby aid in influencing public opinion. However, it remains to be seen what the broader reception is to these comments and I therefore maintain my current predictions.

Update: Public support for impeaching Trump is up by 5% from mid-April, with 45% of the respondents in favor of impeaching Trump. 42 % is in opposition to impeaching Trump. These numbers are especially interesting in relation to similar polls conducted in 1998, when then President Clinton was facing impeachment. Here, ABC/Washington Post Poll found that 40% of the respondents agreed with the impending impeachment, whereas 60% were opposed to it. These numbers are interesting to note, because the failure of the Clinton impeachment, and the president’s subsequent rise in popularity, has been cited as one of the reasons why leading democrats are holding back on initiating the process. However, the polls indicate that President Clinton held a stronger public sympathy than Trump currently does. This means that back-lash, in terms of a popularity gain, that the democrats fear an impeachment process would result in, might not be as likely an outcome. This support the loud voices, like Sens. Elizabeth Warren and Kamala Harris, who are publicly pushing for impeachment.  That being said, it seems that the democrats are not rushing into an impeachment process. Instead, Pelosi is seemingly taking a course of framing their future actions and investigations meant to protect the constitution and the political integrity of the American system. Thereby, Pelosi seems more concerned with establishing unity in her democratic caucus than with the impeachment.  I chose to raise my probability of 5% to 8%, keeping in mind that the house is currently not on clear path to impeachment and that the time frame of this questions in set to before October 1st.  Simultaneously, there are strong voices in the party are still calling for the process to be initiated and public opinion is seemingly increasingly in favor.

The discussions about Trump’s impeachment rose right after he was elected as a president of the United States in 2016. The efforts to finally impeach Donald Trump have been initiated several times already due to different issues and even though we’ve heard different stories of his impeachment during the last 3 years, I do believe there’s low likelihood that the US House of Representatives will pass an article of impeachment against President Trump before October 1, 2019. First of all, after the findings in Mueller report were revealed, last poll regarding Trump’s impeachment still states that the majority of Americans believe that the report should not cause impeachment hearings against Trump. Only 39% claims that Congress must start impeachment hearings. The Mueller report itself included one of the most important controversies we’ve heard surrounding Trump – Russian interference in the 2016 Presidential elections – and proved that the allegations weren’t false, the interference in the elections indeed occurred and violated the US criminal law. The report itself doubts the legitimacy of Trump’s presidency and if he can “survive” this, I don’t think there’s something more significant on the agenda right now that can actually make the US house of representatives pass an article for the impeachment.  Second, since 2019 the risks of his impeachment have increased due to the fact that the Democrats have gained control over the House. In 2017 and 2018 the Republicans controlled both the House and Senate and it’s easy to guess why no significant measures were taken against Trump. In 2017 Democrats even initiated Trump’s impeachment for violations of the foreign emoluments’ clause of the constitution. However, to actually remove Trump from presidency, the US House of Representatives can only pass an article of impeachment (that needs a simple majority of votes) for “treason, bribery, or other high crimes and misdemeanors”. The senate is actually the institution that is able to impeach the president, since the Senate votes to punish the individual or not (a two-third majority of the senators need to vote “guilty”). The two-third majority of votes will be quite difficult to achieve since 53 members of the 116th US congress are from Republican Party and as of today, Trump’s approval within the Republicans is still 90%. Finally, looking into the history of the US, we see that there were only two impeached US presidents – Andrew Johnson and Bill Clinton. The house of Representatives charged them with committing “high crimes and misdemeanors”. However, the Senate didn’t convict neither of them. Hence, until now there has not been a president that’s been removed from the office using the impeachment process.  Taking into consideration the major points discussed above, the House of Representatives should be able to predict what are the actual chances of Trump’s impeachment nowadays and, therefore, shouldn’t present an article that most likely won’t result in Trump’s removal from the office. As much as Democratic leadership might want to put off impeachment at least until it can no longer be used against them as a cudgel to get Trump reelected, ongoing investigations of the president and administration may not give them a choice. Several factors are likely to force their hand: (1) The progressive wing of the party that believes Trump should be impeached no matter the political cost to the party in red and swing states, (2) a need to de-legitimize the Trump presidency both to score political points and mitigate the impacts of what they argue are dangerous policies, and finally, (3) a sense of duty to uphold the rule of law and fulfill Congress' oversight role over the Executive branch. In this climate, it's possible that future revelations from ongoing Congressional investigations, the unredacted Mueller report, and public testimonies from key actors related to the Mueller report may the turn the tide of popular opinion on impeachment. This may give Democratic leadership the political cover they need to pursue Articles of Impeachment in the House of Representatives. The biggest question thus is whether political opinion will change enough in favor of impeachment before 1 October 2019, and that, in turn, will be at least partially determined by how grave and shocking are future revelations about the conduct of Trump and his administration (50% likely). It will also be facilitated in part by whether Republicans are able to get behind a plan B candidate for the next election. Mike Pence has done enough as VP to associate himself with Trump that he may be acceptable to the Trump's base if Trump is out of the picture, but this would be a very unlikely scenario (5% likely). It will also depend on overcoming the fundamental inertia of American public opinion - certainly a significant challenge when it comes to something as serious as impeachment (15% likely). Given the number of things that need to happen before the Democratic leadership is willing to pursue Articles of Impeachment, there is a very low chance that they will do so before October of this year. However, chances are slightly higher given the roughly even probability that there will be further shocking revelations about Trump. Important edit: Apparently, it will help Democrats in their disputes with the administration over documents and testimonies if they are officially pursuing impeachment (https://www.politico.com/story/2019/05/10/democrats-impeachment-trump-1315838). This certainly would increase the chances that they pass Articles of Impeachment before October 2019. However, there is still too much uncertainty about how supportive Democrats are of this idea to make any changes to the prediction at this time.

Forecast Update #3: The struggle in Washington between Congress and the White House over parliamentary control rights after the Mueller report is intensifying. Trump said on Sunday that he was against special investigator Robert Mueller being questioned by Congress about his final report on the Russian investigation. The Democrats should not be allowed to repeat the investigation.  The president reacted with his statement to the news that the Legal Affairs Committee had provisionally set May 15 as the date for the hearing. Trump had only said on Friday that the question of whether Mueller should testify had to be decided by Justice Minister William Barr. However, Barr had recently argued in the hearing before the Senate's Legal Affairs Committee that the White House had the right to refuse to testify before Congress to current and former members of the Presidential Office. That is part of the executive privilege. It is expected that this matter, as well as the refusal to submit the unprocessed final report, will go to court. The House Judiciary Committee would particularly like to summon Don McGahn, former White House counsel, to clarify the question Mueller left open in his final report: Was Trump guilty of obstructing justice? Mueller had described ten episodes in the report in which Trump tried to influence the Russian investigation. Although the member of congress have access to the full report in a classified room, they have not yet been able to publicly use the information, such as information on ongoing court cases.   Democrats refer to the landmark Supreme Court ruling in the Watergate affair, in which Richard Nixon's reference to executive privilege was rejected. As a result, the then president had to hand over his tape recordings from the Oval Office, whereupon he resigned in a courteous impeachment procedure. The Democrats are divided over an impeachment against Trump. Some of the senators and deputies would like to charge him if the parliamentary inquiry confirms the accusation of obstruction of justice. Nancy Pelosi, the "spokeswoman" of the House of Representatives, rejects this with reference to the majority situation in the Senate, which would prevent the dismissal of the president (https://edition.faz.net//faz-edition/politik/2019-05-07/trump-gegen-aussage-muellers-vor-dem-kongress/304081.html/). Due to the lastest developments, I return to my original forecast's estimation of 10%. Chances of the House of Representatives passing an impeachment article against seem still low. However, my latest estimation that there were no further political consequences seemed premature, which is why I decided to add the 3% again.

I consider it to be very unlikely that the House will initiate the impeachment procedure against Trump. There are historical and practical reasons behind that. 
First, throughout the history of the United States, there were two cases when the president was impeached by the House (Andrew Johnson in 1868 and Bill Clinton in 1998). The third case of Richard Nixon was not completed, as he resigned from office before the full House voted on the articles of impeachment. Hence, even though the demands for impeachment, especially of presidents, are quite common, the actual impeachment is a rare event in the U.S. 
Second, as for Trump, demands to impeach him is nothing new. The talks about impeachment against him had begun before Trump took office, while actual efforts to impeach Trump were initiated already during the first year of his presidency back to 2017. As it is known by now, it did not turn into any impeachment proceedings so far.
Third, many experts agreed that at the beginning the impeachment was barely possible practically as Republicans controlled both the House and the Senate. After 2018 elections, when Democrats won control over the House, the expectations about the impeachment have increased. However, even though Democrats have a majority in the House and an actual opportunity to pass an article of impeachment against Trump, it looks like it is still very unlikely to happen before October 2019. Throughout the last 5 months, even though they had a majority, Democrats didn't initiate the impeachment. What is more, from the latest news is known that the speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi urged her fractious rank and file to avoid a broad, open-ended impeachment inquiry as it might backfire for the Democrats in 2020 elections. To my mind, the House could use other punishing tools towards Trump, avoiding the risky option of impeachment. For instance, a Chairman of the Intelligence Committee mentioned another possible way of striking back by using using the so colled House’s power of the purse. 
Forth, I am taking into account the period of time. As the question on impeachment is due October 2019, it also contributes to decline in chances for Trump to be impeached. 
To sum up, as I argued before, the impeachment of Trump is very unlikely. However, I leave 5% chance for it to happen. On my previous argumentation, I deliberately tried to avoid the analysis of specific accusations to Trump as, to my mind, it creates a lot of extra noise that very often misleads the prognosis itself as we tend to give more weight on the impact when it actually has. To my mind, if there is a strong political will, the evidence against Trump might be sufficient to pass an article of impeachment. Especially, adding the latest news of Trump family lawsuit to block oversight of its finances (Subpoenas). Moreover, many compare Trump to Nixon, seeing the same pattern of obstruction of justice by using the power to limit the access to witnesses and documents. However, to sum all the arguments up, I still find it very unlikely to happen.  Sources: 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Impeachment_in_the_United_States
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Efforts_to_impeach_Donald_Trump
https://edition.cnn.com/2019/05/02/opinions/trump-impeachment-isnt-like-clinton-its-nixon-lockhart/index.html

I find it extraordinarily unlikely at this moment in time that the U.S. House of Representatives will pass an article of impeachment against President Trump. The House could easily pass this resolution based on their finding of the Mueller Report. The Report specifically left it to Congress to make a judgment on obstruction of justice and gave a pile of evidence that could be used to make this judgement. This in and of itself presents valid grounds for impeachment as Bill Clinton was impeached in part on grounds of obstruction of justice and Nixon was going to be impeached in part on grounds of obstruction of justice. There are also 16 other investigations that involve Trump and these may also yield impeachable charges. Moreover, The Democrats have a majority in the House and passing an article of impeachment only requires a single member to bring to the floor and only takes a simple majority to pass. In this sense if enacted the actual process will undoubtedly result in an article of impeachment being passed. However, Democrats are not willing to enact this process, making it unlikely that Trump will be impeached by October 2019. There are several reasons why Democrats will not enact the procedure. First, impeachment is just the process of determining whether to send the president and other federal figures to trial. The House has no power in actually removing these figures, that relies wholly in the Senate and to be removed from office the Senate needs to have a trail and then a 2/3 majority is required to find the figure guilty and should be removed from office. This is why no president and very few federal figures have actually been removed, it requires bi-partisan agreement on the issue. Currently, if the Senate were to hold a trial Trump would not be removed. So let's assume all democrats and independents would vote to remove Trump, something unlikely as some Senators from traditional red states like Doug Jones from Alabama or Joe Manchin  from West Virginia  might feel pressure from their constituents to vote no, something already seen in the confirmation process of Brett Kavanaugh. But if all Democrats and independents were to vote for removal, that would only be 47 votes and 66 are needed, meaning 19 Republicans would also have to vote for removal and there are only 2 republican senators who have show some willingness to vote against party lines, those be Lisa Murkowski from Alaska and Susan Collins from Maine. Then you have three other potential Republicans have yet to seriously break party line, but may receive enough pressure from their constituents to vote for removal, those are Pat Toomey from Pennsylvania, Ron Johnson from Wisconsin and Cory Gardner from Colorado. These states had a historically strong showing for democrats in the Midterms, thereby this could put alot of pressure on these Republican Senators. However, this is only 5 Republican Senators who could conceivably vote for removal, which is far short of the needed 14. The remaining Republicans have consistently shown a willingness to ignore any allegations against Trump and continue to blindly pin their political careers on Trumps success and it would take indisputable, damning evidence for them to vote for removal. Yet, this evidence already exists and if it was any other president, especially democrat, the Senate would have alreadry voted to remove the president. Therefore, the shear number of scandals and allegations of Trump have numbed Republicans to the point where they don't care anymore. They've gone from a party that 20 years ago could not stand a President who received a blowjob and lied about it, to completely ignoring any present wrong doings in the White House. Therefore, even if the articles of impeachment are passed in the House, Trump will not be removed.  Democrats, Especially Nancy Pelosi understand this and therefore they will not bring up impeachment charges, because they know that in the end Trump will not removed and the Senate's decision will essentially be an exoneration of his actions, meaning that Democrats will have lost this battle the will not be able to renew charges and it will severely tarnish the checks and balances system by essentially proving that Presidents can get away with almost anything and not be removed from office. Therefore, passing articles of impeachment would solely be a political move and nothing productive would come from this. Thereby, Pelosi has kept a tight reign and will continue to keep a tight reign on House Democrats to prevent them from bringing up the articles of impeachment.  Secondly, as previously stated, their are so many scandals and investigations into Trump, that not only have Republicans become numb to it, but so have many voting Americans, they no longer want to hear about all the awful things Trump has done and they find it complete overkill at this point. Therefore, Democrats with their eyes on the 2020 election recognize that passing articles of impeachment would likely be more harmful for them, because that would be what people hear from the media and it would drown out policy issues and crucial voters will turn off. They'll see a combative democratic party that continues to beat the same drums they've been beating for 5 years and won't listen. They won't see Democratic candidates as being a party for the people who are proposing sweeping changes, they'll just see them as the anti-trump party and this will not convince the essential voters to get up and vote and then vote for democrats.  Many top democrats, like Pelosi, have already voiced this concern and would prefer to hold Trump accountable through elections. Then after the elections they'll either be stuck with Trump for four more years and will have no other option but to use their power and authority to try an remove him or Trump will lose and then charges can be brought against an ex-president who doesn't have any official power to prevent justice.   Therefore, I claim that there is only a 1% chance that the House will pass articles of impeachment by October 1st, because it's not impossible, but Democrats have already voiced that this is not a good option and it makes no political sense due to the fact it has far more potential to harm Democrats than benefit them. All this said, the current democratic position may change if more and more evidence against Trump is revealed and they face more and more pressure from their constituents, or even if republicans start to miraculously abandon  the president. However, at this moment in time there is no indication of this and therefore the probability of a successful impeachment process by October 2019 remains astronomically low.
So far, 45 has decent enough protection but it’s going to collapse. Something bigger than the mueller report will bring him down, although he’s on really shaky ground thus far.

https://thehill.com/homenews/house/440749-some-dem-chairmen-have-changed-tune-on-trump-impeachment?userid=304820 House Democratic chairmen who cast votes in favor of impeaching President Trump while Republicans controlled the chamber now say it’s too soon to hit the gas on starting impeachment proceedings.  The senior Democratic lawmakers, who voted in favor of impeachment articles from Rep. Al Green (D-Texas) in the last Congress, are largely toeing their leadership’s line of caution, saying committees should move forward with investigations of Trump.   The committee leaders who voted in favor of Green's impeachment articles in 2017 and 2018 either once or both times include Foreign Affairs Committee Chairman Eliot Engel (N.Y.), Homeland Security Committee Chairman Bennie Thompson (Miss.), Rules Committee Chairman Jim McGovern (Mass.), Science Committee Chairwoman Eddie Bernice Johnson (Texas), Energy and Commerce Committee Chairman Frank Pallone Jr. (N.J.), Small Business Committee Chairwoman Nydia Velázquez (N.Y.) and Natural Resources Committee Chairman Raúl Grijalva (Ariz.). Engel and Financial Services Committee Chairwoman Maxine Waters (D-Calif.) are both leading investigations of Trump; Waters is notable in having called for Trump’s impeachment before and after the release of special counsel Robert Mueller’s report. Engel, who backed impeachment in separate votes in 2017 and 2018, echoed Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) during a conference call earlier this week with Democrats. Engel said that Democrats “should be cautious” with impeachment, according to a source on the call, while explaining how his panel is investigating Russian interference. “We need to look at this bizarre relationship between Putin and Trump,” Engel said during the call. He added that he’s directing staff to inform foreign governments that do business with Trump hotels that they may be contributing to a violation of the Constitution's Emoluments Clause, which is an issue that progressives like billionaire activist Tom Steyer have cited in calling for impeachment.  Johnson, who also voted in favor of Green’s impeachment resolution, took a similar tack. “Impeachment is a sacred constitutional responsibility entrusted to Congress. I am committed to continuing to conduct oversight into the president’s conduct and wrongdoing as well as serving as a check on the president. This is what House Democrats were elected into the majority to do, and this is what we will do while Senate Republicans repeatedly show that they are willing to look the other way,” Johnson said in a statement.  McGovern deferred to the Judiciary Committee but didn't rule out the prospect of impeachment. "He trusts Chairman [Jerrold] Nadler’s leadership on this issue. But given Special Counsel Mueller’s report and the president’s continued stonewalling of Congressional oversight requests, he doesn’t believe any options should be taken off the table," McGovern spokesman Matt Bonaccorsi said. Two members of Democratic leadership who, like Green, are members of the Congressional Black Caucus, at one point or another supported the efforts. Green alleged in his articles of impeachment that Trump was inflaming racial tensions in America. House Majority Whip James Clyburn (D-S.C.) voted in favor of Green's articles of impeachment in 2017 but joined other Democratic leaders the second time in voting to table them. The votes forced by Green drew the support of 58 Democrats the first time and 66 a month later, but the majority of his colleagues joined leadership in rejecting the efforts. “His vote in 2017 was to express his disapproval of the president on the record,” Clyburn spokeswoman Hope Derrick said. House Democratic Caucus Chairman Hakeem Jeffries (D-N.Y.), voted to table Green's articles the first time but voted in favor of them in January 2018 after Trump came under fire for deriding protections for immigrants from “shithole” African countries. Democratic chairmen face some pressure to back Pelosi, who has argued it would be unwise to move forward with impeachment given the likelihood that the Republican Senate would not convict Trump. Pelosi also remembers how impeachment boomeranged on House Republicans in the Clinton era. Most of the calls to move forward on impeachment have come from liberal members of the Democratic caucus. Pelosi is worried impeachment could be used by Republicans against many of the vulnerable Democrats who won swing districts in 2018. Waters is one committee chair who backed Green’s call for impeachment when Democrats were in the minority, and has kept her position in the majority. In the wake of Mueller’s report, she said she still supports impeachment.  “Mueller kicked the impeachment ball to the Congress. The Constitution gives the responsibility to Congress to impeach an unfit president — 'high crimes and misdemeanors.' What more do we need? #impeach45,” Waters wrote in a series of tweets this week.  She also made a point of noting that impeachment is in House Judiciary Committee Chairman Jerry Nadler's (D-N.Y.) court, writing that “Dems divided. The impeachment resolution must start with & be taken up by the Judiciary Committee. Rep. Nadler is the Chairman of the Judiciary Committee.” Nadler, as well as Oversight and Reform Committee Chairman Elijah Cummings (D-Md.) and Intelligence Committee Chairman Adam Schiff (D-Calif.), did not vote in favor of Green's efforts. Thompson, meanwhile, notably retweeted a message from Green last week calling for impeachment. A spokesman for Thompson did not return requests for comment. Other committee leaders who voted in favor of Green's articles in the past avoided mentioning the word impeachment at all when reacting to the release of Mueller's report and instead joined calls for the full, unredacted version of the special counsel's findings. Both Pallone and Velazquez cast doubt on Attorney General William Barr and said they wanted to see Mueller testify before Congress. Grijalva, meanwhile, indicated that impeachment isn't a realistic option compared to asking voters to make the decision whether to oust Trump. “Election time is when you beat Trump,” Grijalva told Politico. Green told The Hill that he's waiting to see what the Judiciary Committee does next before forcing a third vote on impeachment, which he’s threatened since February.  Green has cosponsored articles of impeachment from Rep. Brad Sherman (D-Calif.) arguing that Trump obstructed justice by firing James Comey as FBI director as well as a resolution from Rep. Rashida Tlaib (D-Mich.) calling on the House Judiciary Committee to investigate whether Trump has committed impeachable offenses. But Green has yet to unveil a new impeachment resolution of his own this year. “I'm going to give the committee an opportunity to act,” Green said in a phone interview. “But if the committee doesn't act, I'm not going to let my record show that a president who was unfit, who has obstructed justice, is above the law.” Green said that he's not lobbying colleagues on impeachment, saying that “under these circumstances, it is better to stand alone than not stand at all.”

https://twitter.com/RepJerryNadler/status/1119226892748562433?s=19 'Following a subpoena from the Judiciary Committee, in April 1974 edited transcripts of many Watergate-related conversations from the Nixon White House tapes were made public by Nixon, but the committee pressed for full tapes and additional conversations. Nixon refused, but on July 24, the U.S. Supreme Court ordered him to comply. On July 27, 29, and 30, 1974, the Committee approved three articles of impeachment against Nixon, for obstruction of justice, abuse of power, and contempt of Congress, and reported those articles to the House of Representatives. Two other articles of impeachment were debated but not approved. Before the House could vote on the impeachment resolutions, Nixon made public one of the additional conversations, known as the "Smoking Gun Tape", which made clear his complicity in the cover-up. With his political support completely eroded, Nixon resigned from office on August 9, 1974.' https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Impeachment_process_against_Richard_Nixon

In US history, only 2 presidents have been impeached: Andrew Johnson in 1868, and more recently, Bill Clinton in 1998. Moreover, Richard Nixon was expecting impeachment in 1974 before he resigned. 
The rarity of an actual impeachment indicates the seriousness of the act, as it could result in the removal of a publicly elected state leader. The US constitution lists “treason, bribery, or other high crimes and misdemeanors” as reasons for impeachment; evidently the charges have to be very grave to warrant such an article to pass. 
While Trump has been an extremely polarizing president since he took office, and has been surrounded by serious allegations of financial crimes and Russian collusion since then, several key factors need to be considered. 
Firstly, the result of the recent Mueller report (in the form of the summary that has been made available to the public) did not establish a connection between the Trump presidential campaign and Russia. Consequently, it failed to give the President’s opponents a secure proof of Russian ties and as of now does not seem like grounds for taken such political action. 
This has been supported by the speaker of the house, Nancy Pelosi, who has expressed her hesitancy in relation to an impeaching the president, underlining the dividing effects such a decision would have on the country. That being said, there are still significant forces in the democratic party supporting impeachment, and their further actions will likely be dependent upon the both the results of the investigation ongoing investigations (e.g. the House Judiciary Committee’s investigation into Trump’s campaign and finances), as well as on how the Mueller report will play out, when/if it is released in its full length. 
Moreover, it could be damaging for the democrats to initiate an impeachment process in the house, only to have it rejected by the senate. Especially this close to an election. Additionally, there would need to be a strong, broad, public support for the impeachment, across party lines, which does not seem to be the case currently. 
On the basis of the rarity of impeachments in the past, the vagueness of the result of the Mueller report, and the reluctance of top democrats to support an impeachment of the sitting president, I deem this event very unlikely.

The probability of this event happening is higher than 0. The reason it is higher than 0 is that Trump has already passed the threshold of actions at which previous presidents were impeached. E.g. Clinton. This fact alone raises the probability above 0. However, the democratic leadership (Pelosi, specifically) has indicated strongly that they do not intend to impeach Trump, so there would need to be a catalyzing event that would change the House Leadership's mind in order for impeachment proceedings to go ahead. This counterweight lowers the probability of impeachment to near 0, but not all the way to 0 due to the possibility of a "Black Swan" catalyst changing the political calculus during the timeframe of this forecast. Impeachment is a political act and Pelosi has shown a lack of political will to take this act under current political conditions. This brings us on to catalyzing events that could, in fact, lead to impeachment: What might those events be? There are two types. 1. A change of leadership in the house. This is highly unlikely in the time frame and can be ruled out. 2. The release of new information pertaining to Trump's "guilt". While this information may exist in the real world, there's no obvious mechanism (currently) for its release. Moreover. Even were such information to be released, Trump has a track record of disavowing information (whether it is true or not) that shows him in a negative light. When he disavows negative information he continues to carry about 40% of the country with him and we've probably reached the point where there's no disclosure of information that would change the mind of this 40%. This 40% all but guarantees that Republican leadership in the house would stick with Trump, even in the event of potentially "extreme" revelations about him - and the loyalty of the house Republicans to Trump, along with the risk of political violence in the event of impeachment has the House Democrats convinced that impeachment is a counter-productive path for them to pursue for Trump's removal, even if "smoking gun" evidence were to be released, itself a highly unlikely outcome in the first place. The reason for the dem's strategy of "don't impeach" under any new information disclosure scenario is four-fold 1. Senate Republican support would be required for a conviction (this is unlikely in the extreme) 2. Previous impeachments have not benefitted the impeaching parties in polls (Clinton / Starr) 3. There's a non-trivial risk of political violence, instigated in part by Trump, in the event of impeachment proceedings going ahead. This violence could negatively impact democrats's ability to regain power in a foreseeable time frame. 4. The threat of impeachment without actually going ahead with it is, in fact, a check on Trump instigating political violence against his opponents in the meantime. The thought process being that once he's actually been impeached, there are no more sanctions to restrain him from going down this path: a path he's indicated a preference for on a number of occasions. For these reasons, the odds of impeachment are negligible, as close to 0 as possible, but not 0.

According to the fact that hating Trump policy and criticising his lack of values  is not enough to kick him out of the White House, I asset the possibility of passing an impeachment article for president Trump only at 5% because of the following reasons.
- Looking at the previous cases of impeachment procedures, no president has been dismissed, but in two cases the procedure has been put in place, the House of Representatives have emanated an article and the Senate has voted (for Johonson in 1868 and Clinton in 1997). Nixon too was almost impeached, but he resigned before that the procedure started. Data show me that in the US impeachment for president has never resolved in a dismission and only few times in history it has been used. 
- Impeachment is a hard procedure. It is possible to impeach someone for “treason, bribery and high crimes and misdemeanours”. The last one is the vaguest of the three, so it can be interpreted quite liberally, in a restrictive or extensive way. In this case, it’s used also to accuse Trump of “obstructing justice, accepting what’s known as emoluments, sowing racial discord and undermining the federal judiciary”.
- Usually, is the reason to which the Representatives bring into play, because it’s easier to manipulate. However, the entire impeachment procedure is long and complex.
- To be emanated by the House of Representatives, the impeachment article needs to take the simple majority (218 out of 435). Today, Democrats control only 193 seats (indeed, in both the House of R. and the Senate Republicans have the majority). 
- To obtain enough votes the Democrats should find allies between the Republicans, in particular the ones that disagree with the president governance. However, even among them, only very few exceptions want to implement the impeachment procedure.
- Talking about the reason of the impeachment, the possible charges are: Trump personal returns from its policies (tax, health care education, immigration), abuse of power in an effort “to punish companies associated with news outlets that have reported critically on him, including CNN and The Washington Post.”, Trump collusion with Russia (Russiagate). However, they are all difficult to demonstrate.
- Moreover, the special counsel R. Muller is overseeing the criminal investigation into Russia interference in 2016 campaign, but a couple of weeks ago from its report emerged that there is no evidence of collusion (even if this didn’t clear him of the charges). Investigations continues, but the idea of the impeachments is getting away.
- More than half of Trump presidency is already passed, and the elections will take place in 2020. Also, the impeachment procedure is long and complex. Therefore, It’s not worthy for the Democrats to impeach Trump now because they could more easily prepare the electoral campaign.
- Impeachment could be even counter-productive for the Democrats, because they could be depicted as those who wanted to get rid of Trump through impeachment because unable to compete properly during the next election. Also, they can be seen as the ones who has been dismissed “because he was doing well”. 
*Nevertheless, impeachment could be a (risky) strategy for Democrats if applied enough quick (before the end of 2019), because during the procedure Trump might lose a huge part of its consensus, to the benefit of the Democrats. https://www.tpi.it/2017/05/18/come-funziona-impeachment-stati-uniti/

An article of impeachment against a President implies that he has committed a "high crime" or misdemeanours. However, this procedure is very demanding, difficult and rare, proven by history. Only two American presidents have been confronted to an article of impeachment from the U.S House of Representatives: Johnson and Clinton.  Donal Trump is highly criticized, mistrusted and unpopular among the opposition. Technically, an article of impeachment could relatively easily reach the majority (51%) within the House of Representatives. If the U.S House of Representatives was to pass an article of impeachment against President Trump, it would be expected from them to be sure regarding their accusation of high crime or misdemeanours, in order to succeed the impeachment. Regarding the “Russia gate”, Mueller’s report has not been able to show collusion between Trump and Moscow in the Presidential elections of 2016. The impeachment process is laid down in the US Constitution to dismiss a president, vice-president or senior official. It is based upon the system of checks and balances that ensures the separation of powers. Congress may dismiss officers before their term of office expires. According to Article 2(4), the reasons for initiating the procedure may be the following: high treason, bribery or other serious crimes and misconduct. The question at hand, explicitly limits itself to the likelihood of an impeachment article against Trump passed by the House of Representatives, which is unlike the Senate lead by the Democrats at this point in time. Thus, a simple majority against Republican Trump would be possible, even though most likely unsuccessful due to the majority of the Republicans in the Senate.  Base-rate for the forecast at hand is the history of impeachment procedures in the US history. Only two presidents, Johnson in 1868 and Clinton in 1998 were impeached by the House of Repräsentatives (Nixon resigned before a corresponding vote could be hold). Given the 45 presidents (Cleveland counted twice) the impeachment quote is only 4,4%.  However, the forecast at hand adds further 5.6% on this base rate due to the high degree of uncertainty aligned with the presidency of Trump, the majority of Democrats in the House of Representatives, as well as the not yet completely enclosed political consequences of the report of FBI special investigator Müller. Mueller investigated whether there had been secret agreements between Trump's campaign and Moscow and whether Trump had obstructed justice by dismissing FBI chief James Comey in May 2017. Mueller’s report comes to the conclusion that there had been no secret agreements. Not so clear are Mueller's findings on the second point, whether Trump had obstructed the judiciary. Neither does the report find him guilty, nor non-guilty. Instead, Mueller would have listed evidences for both points, based upon which Attorney General Barr decided not press charges against Trump. So far, Congress has only seen a summary of the report and Democrats are pushing for a soon hearing. Thus, even though unlikely a further escalation is cannot be excluded completely.

The house of representatives has only ever charged two presidents with committing high crimes and misdemeanours. That is, only 2 out of 44 presidents (4.5%). But neither of the two impeached presidents were charged by the senate. There has never been a president removed from office using this process.  Will Trump be brought be brought before the House? 
The democrats have hinted at starting an impeachment process.  But threats to do so are not uncommon. In addition to Trump, the two presidents preceding (Obama and Bush) also endured suggestions they should be impeached: indicating a threat to impeach does not amount to any actual action. This is a consideration of this forecast. Nevertheless, with control of the house, impeachment is definitely possible — as long as they can establish high crimes and misdemeanours. But this may prove difficult. While surrounded by scandal, many of the activities which may qualify as such occurred before the term of Trump's presidency. Last year, 5 separate democrats brought forth articles of impeachments to the judicial committee. These have not yet been pursued, with the chair of the judiciary committee ‘taking a ‘’wait and see’’ approach to the idea of impeachment’ (The Conversation, 31 Jan 2019). It seems the committee had been waiting for more concrete evidence of high crimes and misdemeanours — perhaps anticipating damaging information to emerge out of the Mueller report. We know now that a conspiracy between Trump’s 2016 campaign and Russia was not established, nor did he obstruct justice (though not totally exonerated, mind you). With the big opportunity for establishing grounds to move forward with the impeachment process not delivering, it seems highly unlikely that the democrats will unveil new information that will prove misdemeanours and high crimes. In addition, the very low likelihood of the impeachment passing with a high majority in the Senate (given it is controlled by republicans and it has never happened before) means that the potential crime which permit the process would have to be so abhorrent, and proven beyond reasonable doubt, for Democrats to feel confident that the process will bring about Trump’s removal (if that is their goal).  All of this suggests that an article of impeachment is unlikely to be brought to the House of Representatives before October 1. It is forecasted at 5% -- close to the base rate of previously impeached presidents.  Today though, the House Judiciary authorised the subpoena of the full Mueller report — once revealed, its content may be grounds for altering this forecast. But for now, it remains relatively low.

First of all, it must be considered that the question is not about the effectiveness of a complete impeachment agaisnt Trump, but rather if the House of Representatives - with a liberal party majority after the 2018's midterm elections - will pass an article of impeachment. First, an article of impeachment can arise only from suspected presdential acts of treason, bribery, or other high crimes and misdemeanors. I don't want to suggest that, with the appropriate reasons, an impeachment is useless right before the president ceases to have its presidency anyway, but given the historical difficulty in concluding an impeachment procedure - as most knows, the impeachment in the US never happened, and the only impeachment that could have actually worked ended with Nixon's resignation - I would say that the House of Representatives don't have many incentives in igniting an impeachment procedure. The current context of American politics shows a certain polarization of the bipartisan divide. So it is often mentioned Impeachment vis-à-vis Trump. Context of Impeachment:
Impeachment is the fact that an American president “shall be removed from office on impeachment for, and conviction of, treason, bribery, or other high crimes and misdemeanors “(http://fortune.com/2018/11/07/will-democrats-impeach-trump/). For Trump, it should be certain that he committed "high crimes and misdemeanors" that would warrant an attempt to remove him from office.
History of Impeachment:
Technically, there has never been a successful US President's Impeachment. 
Historically, the United States House of Representatives has voted indictment only seventeen times, out of just over sixty cases; only three procedures concerned presidents. The two proceedings passed the House of Representatives were: Andrew Johnson (for firing his secretary of war) in 1868 and Bill Clinton (for obstruction of justice) in 1998. Nevertheless, the Senate, having the majority of supporters of their camps each time, saved them (indeed it takes 2/3 of the Senate, or 67 senators for the conviction). Nixon, most likely to remove his post, resigned himself in 1974, when it became clear he would be impeached by the House and convicted by the Senate.
To pass an Impeachement article, you need the majority vote of the House.
It should be noted that on all Impeachment articles, the procedure for a president is relatively very rare (much less rare for judges). The two suspicions of Trump's criminal acts resulting in the possibility of being impeached:
Collusion between Trump and Russia (the most « pushing Trump to the exit »): Special Counsel Robert Mueller, who is overseeing the criminal investigation into Russian interference in the 2016 campaign, could choose to submit a written report to Congress alleging misdeeds by Trump ( http://fortune.com/2018/11/07/will-democrats-impeach-trump/)
Trump's involvement in a criminal act: for example, the payment of hush money to two women before the 2016 election, as Michael Cohen, Trump’s former personal lawyer, alleged.  Current US Congress Context:
Current Senate Composition: 53 Republicans (Majority) out of 100 Senators
Composition of the House of Representatives: 235 Democrats vs 199 Republicans
Note also the next US election on November 3, 2020 Forecast:
In my opinion, it seems highly improbable to me that an Impeachment move goes to House in the context of today. Indeed, the most damaging case for Trump, the collusion with Russia, finally came to an end. On March 24, 2019, Justice Minister William Barr presented the findings of Special Prosecutor Robert Mueller on this case. The latter reports that the Special Prosecutor's investigations into possible Russian interference in the 2016 campaign have not shown that "the Trump campaign team or anyone associated with it has agreed or coordinated with Russia in his efforts to influence the 2016 US presidential election. " In addition, the scope of the Mueller investigation is not to be taken lightly: "The special prosecutor employed 19 lawyers assisted by a team of 40 FBI agents, intelligence analysts, forensic accountants; with 2,800 subpoenas, 500 search warrants, 13 requests for evidence to foreign governments and about 500 witnesses interviewed "according to the Minister of Justice.
In a second step, the other point examined by the report, namely a possible obstruction of justice by Donald Trump, "does not conclude that the president has committed a crime, but does not exonerate him" . The Minister of Justice, he said that the investigation did not mention any offense likely to lead to prosecution on this point.
As for the other possibility of a criminal offense (hush money during the campaign), it certainly seems difficult to determine the veracity of that. Michael Cohen made that allegation while pleading guilty on Aug. 21 to tax evasion, making false statements to a bank and making illegal campaign contributions.
It should also be noted that before the resolution of the Russian file, in full uncertainty about the collusion with Russia, in the 115th Congress, two House votes on impeachment resolution, were defeated 364-58 in December 2017 and 355-66 in January 2018. This shows a heavy defeat of the small fraction of democrats wanting impeachment of Trump, and therefore of the democrats' split on this subject. The launch of a serious effort towards impeachment is far from certaine due to the fact that the question of impeachment may lead to fissures within the party. Now that the report concludes that there was no collusion and that Trump is not charged anywhere for criminal offenses, an Impeachment that passes the House seems concretely impossible. According to the NY Times, this conclusion of the case lifts "the darkest and most threatening cloud that hovered over the presidency" and "remove the question of President Trump's removal from office", despite the Democrats' promise advance on other investigations.
It should also be noted that the Senate will not vote Impeachment if it is ultimately formulated, and a presidential election is close, so it is good to avoid fragmenting before.
Despite the demand of US citizens to dismiss Trump, because of disagreements with his policy, an Impeachment measure is not an option. Indeed, it is not the dismantling of environmental protections, the skepticism about Climate Change or the measures taken regarding immigration, that are actions that can legitimize an Impeachment measure. No matter what one thinks of Trump's policy, it is not criminal, because it is legal, and therefore an Impeachment is not a viable and possible remedy.
