This will obviously be swayed heavily by the findings of the Mueller investigation, thus it's quite apparent that this is a bit of a shot in the dark without a solid idea on what the likely outcomes of the investigation are. So to pose a few sub-questions...
 1a) Will the Special Counsel investigation report findings of collusion between the Trump campaign & the Russian government?
 1b) In the event that the Special Counsel does find such evidence, is it such that Trump himself is indicted?
 2) Will the Special Counsel report findings that justify/recommend indictment of Trump on other charges?
 3) In the event of an indictment, what are the odds of a Democratically controlled House passing articles of impeachment? On point 1a...
 - As reported by The Spectator; "... Mueller wants to indict the President but Barr doesn’t – while the two men agree that Trump’s children should be charged...". From what I can find The Spectator is generally considered right-center biased but generally factual. As such I would say I consider this report to be likely-true (65-85%)
Source: https://spectator.us/mueller-barr-battle-indict-trump/
On point 1b...
 - As reported in the same article above, the indictment of Trump himself is contested. It is difficult to assess a likelihood on this going one way or another, but it is worth noting that if Mueller issues a suggestion for indictment this information will legally have to become public anyways. Thus, given 1a is true & Mueller recommends a Trump indictment as a result the outcome in this question is likely the same.
On point 2...
 - Given the recent indictment of other Trump campaign personnel (Lost of lying to federal agents, a couple counts of obstruction, failure to report serving as a foreign agent, campaign finance violations, etc...) & the statements made by Michael Cohen (explicitly stating that Trump committed many similar violations of the law), I would say this is certainly plausible if not likely at this point.
On point 3...
 - Even if placing the given odds above at 50/50 for case 1 & 2 respectively would place 75% odds on Trump being implicated in a Mueller report. However I'll place my initial anchor points as 1:75% & 2:65% with both considered mutually exclusive. Thus giving a probability of either one or the other occurring as 91%.
 - As far as the HoR filing articles of impeachment if either were to occur, I would say all but guaranteed (> 99%)  and given the majority of the Dem. control similar odds on it passing. However what would be the odds of it occurring prior to January 1st? That's the important bit. I would say there are the following likely periods that democratic leadership would look to act...
 a) Prior to the peak of the Republican Primary campaign period to ensure that such a move at least promoted Republicans to contest Trump as the R. 2020 candidate (~6-months prior to the first caucus (Iowa in February 2020), thus around August 2019)
 b) Immediately following (+ < 1 month) release of the Mueller report
 c) Near the RNC (Late August 2020)
 d) During the 2020 General Election
I would personally posit odds of [15%, 75%, 5%, 5%] respectively (Only real precedent to go off here would be the Nixon & Clinton impeachment articles, one of which was immediately following the special investigation report (Clinton) and one which preceded it (Nixon)). Thus as the first two would conclude prior to January 1st 2020 the combined is 90%. Running everything through gives me approximately 80% for Yes.

Only two presidents have actually been impeached in the last 151 years.  One other would have been impeached in my estimation, but he resigned.  Base rate = 3/151 = 2% Under Pelosi's leadership, the House will only pass an article of impeachment if it thinks the circumstances of that impeachment will also have enough support in the senate to remove the president from office.  The odds for this bipartisan response are low and hinge on Mueller finding a smoking gun or any of the other ongoing investigations digging up something big.  The reasoning is a failed impeachment attempt would be damaging to the democratic party and could strengthen Trumps support in the next election (similar to what happened with Clinton).  Therefore, the far better strategy for dems than swinging for the fences and going for an impeachment is to be patient, wait and see what Mueller and others find out, and continue to let ongoing investigations drum up negative news about Trump that could potentially weaken support in the next election.   However, while historical odds are low for a presidential impeachment, I believe they are elevated in this circumstance.  This is supported by the President's misbehavior, the numerous ongoing investigations, guilty pleas, and evidence of smaller crimes.  Therefore, I increase the base rate by 50% to account for the higher risk in this scenario.   Reduction for time passed:  The house will have to pass an article of impeachment in the next 6 months.  Therefore, I reduce the probability by 6/12. 2% base rate increased by 50% for higher risk reduced by 50%  for passage of time = 2% chance Overall, I think the chances are low. After writing  my forecast below, I looked at the other forecasts and noted a lot of them included polling predictions.  It is true that about 40 percent of the population will oppose Trump's impeachment no matter what.  However, support for his impeachment, which is now at about 45 percent, would have to rise to 55 to 60 percent for the house to vote for impeachment.  I think the odds of this happening are about even.  Even so, it does not change what I wrote below.   Such a high number would be a condition precedent, not sufficient condition, for passing articles of impeachment.   Nevertheless, I think impeachment would be fairly certain with more than 60 percent support because it would resolve Nancy Pelosi's concerns.  Nancy Pelosi is clearly worried that passing an article of impeachment without strong public support could severely backfire--perhaps guaranteeing Trump's reelection.  For that reason, there  would have to be strong bipartisan public support,, and impeachment would have to be viewed as an act that was not merely a futile attempt to embarrass the president.  The key is the nature and extent of evidence of wrongdoing  Muller and the house investigation uncover and make public.  Such evidence  would have to be sufficient that a number of Republican senators  would vote for impeachment.  There are a few who would consider it such as Susan Collins and Lisa Murkowski.  However, I think Pelosi will want at at the very least a senate majority  before allowing  articles to go forward, and that would require two more Republican votes.  I am not sure she could get them. I suspect Muller and the house investigation will find evidence sufficient for the public to support impeachment since what is publicly known right now suggests Trump is a crook  (e.g., Trump University, Cohen's testimony regarding fraud, and his property management history), and the campaign did collude with the Russians (e.g., Trump Jr's, Kushner's and Flynn's contacts with Russians -- and repeatedly lying about them -- during the campaign, and Campaign Manger Manifort's sharing of confidential polling data with the Russians to name just a few).    Any evidence in support of impeachment will excite the left wing of the Democratic Party but will also excite the right wing of the Republican Party just as much.  Pelosi will keep the left wing of the party  in check by reminding them that the impeachment of President Clinton cost the Republicans in the following election because the public did not feel impeachment was justified by Clinton's wrongdoing.  The Republicans impeached Clinton to satisfy their base, and it cost them.  She will not make the same mistake.  Moreover, the Republicans will argue the voters should decide these issues, and this argument will gain more acceptance as the 2020 election approaches. To balance the competing factors, I think the strong evidence of wrongdoing and desire of the left for impeachment will be outweighed by the futility of the act (in that the Republican Senate will never vote to impeach), the risk of backlash in the 2020 election and the desire of the voters to  decide.    However, there is also a good chance that so much evidence of serious wrongdoing, including Russian collusion, could be made public that the house will vote for articles of impeachment, and a number of purple state Republicans would vote for it --  not enough for impeachment-- or have their reelection chances diminished.

From the Democrats' point of view, it's probably  better to go up against Trump in 2020 than an alternative. Bernie Sanders etc are already hitting the campaign trail in a fashion and Trump is a focus for their disquiet.  Also,  it would risk alienating  people who voted for Trump including some swinging voters.

I see two parts to this question: 
1. Is impeachment likely?
2. will it be before 1 October 2019? Is impeachment likely?
I think it is probable that the democratic house would pass an article of impeachment against Trump. Although few US presidents have ever been impeached and the base rate for impeachment is therefore low, I think the situation today allows for it. 
Trump is a controversial president and the tension between the parties is high. There are legal issues and accusations against Trump and his people. Many people criminalize Trump and the left-leaning media, as well as the politicians, reinforce this message constantly. This general opinion is making it inevitable for the democratic party to do something of consequence. Impeachment is the implied consequence for suspectedly crooked presidents. 
Mrs Pelosi and other Democrats have said that they want to build their actions on the results of the Mueller investigation. Justly so. However, creating a clear picture of Trump's machinations is most certainly hard. Potential hard crimes, in this case, are difficult to prove. I can hardly imagine the final Mueller report being a clear-cut case for impeachment. Probably the Mueller report will be legalistic, complex and judicially somewhat ambivalent. Nevertheless, I think there is enough political pressure to pass an article of impeachment in the house, should the Mueller report confirm some misdeeds. I think the pressure to impeach would win, even when the report is oblique and even if it is clear that the article would never pass in the Senate.  Will it happen before 1 October 2019?
 In order for the article of impeachment to pass before 1 October 2019, Mueller needs to finish his report before this date and the house needs to agree on the content of the article. 
On average, special counsel investigations take 904 days. Mueller was appointed 643 days ago. If Mueller finishes his report on 1 October, he will have taken 866 days for his investigation (less than the average). I think the case is big and complex enough to warrant an average investigation period.
Drafting and agreeing on the articles of impeachment and all the processes surrounding the passing of an article of impeachment also takes time. Looking at the time it takes for a bill to pass into law as a reference, I found an average of 263 days (https://www.quora.com/How-long-does-it-take-to-pass-a-bill-in-the-US). The time needed to pass a bill in parliament is certainly less. However, even if it takes half the average time it takes for a bill to pass into law (about 130 days), we are talking about months, not days.
With 223 days to go until 1 October, it seems very unlikely the article will pass before October 1.

Lowry, R., A. (2019). Presidential Impeachment: The Legal Standard and Procedure
https://litigation.findlaw.com/legal-system/presidential-impeachment-the-legal-standard-and-procedure.html The involuntary removal of a sitting President of the United States has never occurred in our history. The only legal way such can be accomplished is by the impeachment process. This article discusses the legal standard to be properly applied by members of the U.S. House of Representatives when voting for or against Articles of Impeachment, and members of the U.S. Senate when voting whether to convict and remove from office a President of the U.S., as well as the procedure to be followed. Article I § 2 of the United States Constitution gives the House of Representatives the sole power to impeach (make formal charges against) and Article I § 3 gives the Senate the sole power to try impeachments. Article II § 4 of the Constitution provides as follows: "The President, Vice President and all civil officers of the United States, shall be removed from office on impeachment for, and conviction of, treason, bribery, or other high crimes and misdemeanors."
Thus, the operative legal standard to apply to an impeachment of a sitting President is "treason, bribery, or other high crimes and misdemeanors." There is substantial difference of opinion over the interpretation of these words. There are essentially four schools of thought concerning the meaning of these words, although there are innumerable subsets within those four categories. Congressional Interpretation The first general school of thought is that the standard enunciated by the Constitution is subject entirely to whatever interpretation Congress collectively wishes to make: "What, then, is an impeachable offense? The only honest answer is that an impeachable offense is whatever a majority of the House of Representatives considers it to be at a given moment in history; conviction results from whatever offense or offenses two-thirds of the other body considers to be sufficiently serious to require removal of the accused from office..." Congressman Gerald Ford, 116 Cong. Rec. H.3113-3114 (April 15, 1970). This view has been rejected by most legal scholars because it would have the effect of having the President serve at the pleasure of Congress. However there are some, particularly in Congress, who hold this opinion. An Indictable Crime The second view is that the Constitutional standard makes it necessary for a President to have committed an indictable crime in order to be subject to impeachment and removal from office. This view was adopted by many Republicans during the impeachment investigation of President Richard M. Nixon. The proponents of this view point to the tone of the language of Article II § 4 itself, which seems to be speaking in criminal law terms. There are other places in the Constitution which seem to support this interpretation, as well. For example, Article III § 2 (3) provides that "the trial of all crimes, except in cases of impeachment, shall be by jury." Clearly the implication of this sentence from the Constitution is that impeachment is being treated as a criminal offense, ergo, impeachment requires a criminal offense to have been committed. Article II § 2 (1) authorizes the President to grant pardons "for offenses against the United States, except in cases of impeachment." This sentence implies that the Framers must have thought impeachment, and the acts which would support impeachment, to be criminal in nature. In the past, England had used impeachment of the King's ministers as a means of controlling policy (Parliament could not get rid of the King, but could get rid of his ministers who carried out acts Parliament believed to be against the best interest of the country). However, in English impeachments, once convicted that person was not only removed from office but was also punished (usually by execution). Misdemeanor The third approach is that an indictable crime is not required to impeach and remove a President. The proponents of this view focus on the word "misdemeanor" which did not have a specific criminal connotation to it at the time the Constitution was ratified. This interpretation is somewhat belied by details of the debate the Framers had in arriving at the specific language to be used for the impeachment standard. Initially the standard was to be "malpractice or neglect of duty." This was removed and replaced with "treason, bribery, or corruption." The word "corruption" was then eliminated. On the floor during debate the suggestion was made to add the term "maladministration." This was rejected as being too vague and the phrase "high crimes and misdemeanors" was adopted in its place. There are many legal scholars who believe this lesser standard is the correct one, however. Relating to the President's Official Duties The fourth view is that an indictable crime is not required, but that the impeachable act or acts done by the President must in some way relate to his official duties. The bad act may or may not be a crime but it would be more serious than simply "maladministration." This view is buttressed in part by an analysis of the entire phrase "high crimes or misdemeanors" which seems to be a term of art speaking to a political connection for the bad act or acts. In order to impeach it would not be necessary for the act to be a crime, but not all crimes would be impeachable offenses. Some hold the opinion that Congress could pass laws by declaring what constitutes "high crimes and misdemeanors" which would, in effect, be a list of impeachable offenses. That has never happened. (Query: If Congress passed such a code of impeachable offenses, could that be applied retroactively, much as a definition, to a sitting President? Would such an application be viewed as an ex post facto law? Also, would such a statue be an attempt to amend the Constitution, without following the amendment procedure?) Ellis, C., M. (1867). The Causes for Which a President Can Be Impeached. The Atlantic. Politics.  Retrieved from
https://www.theatlantic.com/magazine/archive/1867/01/the-causes-for-which-a-president-can-be-impeached/548144/

Since the time President Trump assumed office on January 20th, 2017, the Democratic Party has been threatening to issue articles of impeachment against the Commander and Chief for his negligence and irresponsibility . A few notable Democratic Party leaders who have called for the Presidents impeachment include, but are not limited to: Nancy Pelosi, Bernie Sanders, and Chuck Schumer. With control of the U.S. House of Representatives having a democratic majority, there is a chance that an article of impeachment could presumably be passed, however, I think this is more of a propaganda piece for the Democratic leaders to rally their base and garner support for upcoming elections. In the hypothetical situation that an article of impeachment is passed against President Trump, a super majority is needed in the U.S. Senate in order to convict a federal official. Now, lets entertain the thought that the Republican majority in the senate sides with the House Democrats and passes the articles of impeachment; President Trump is impeached and his successor would be none other that Vice President Pence. In this hypothetical situation, President Trump would seem like the clear choice when given the alternative of a Pence Presidency rather than a Trump. This is not to say that the House won't try their luck and pass an article of impeachment for the sole purpose of rallying their base, but the likelihood of the House actually passing articles of impeachment are very low.  I don't think that democrats want to travel down this rabbit hole, but they could impeach him, but I don't think the Senate will convict him.

We may be approaching a convergence of forces that, almost by accident, make it easy to impeach - and actually remove - Trump. The first factor is Trump's surrender on the wall. There are still people who stick to the "Trump is playing 3-dimensional chess" model, but it seems to me that opinion has always been an example of overthinking. Ann Coulter is the best example of a pro-Trump pundit who has given up on him. There are others. They appear to be a minority at the moment, and according to USA Today, polls indicate that Trump's base is still solid: https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2019/01/28/shutdown-donald-trumps-base-cave-poll/2701887002/ However, in the end, Trump has to deliver something on immigration; this is his signature issue. If he does not unequivocally "win" on immigration, his base may begin to change its mind about him. Trump's penchant for excuses, blame-shifting, and transparent exaggeration may not be indulged if he abandons his hard-line stance on border security. So I don't think the support reflected in current polls will hold if Trump gets no concessions on border security. The second factor is the institutional Republican Party, especially represented by the Republican caucus in the Senate. They never liked Trump anyway, and did everything they could to stop him until the very last minute, when they aligned with him because they had no choice. So far, they have been unable to defy Trump because he is a proven vote getter, standard bearer of the anti-progressives, and champion of the "deplorables." So if you're a Republican candidate in a red state or a red district in a blue states -  you need him. Unless, of course, he has alienated his electoral base, in which case he is not an asset and may be a liability. Trump himself has identified the wall as his issue. He may be dumb enough to believe that he is idolized to such an extent that he can turn on a dime and completely reverse himself on the wall. He can't. So what it comes down to is that if Trump loses a significant portion of his voters, the Republican Party - which never wanted him as its leader - may be willing (and happy) to dump him. And then we would get President Pence, who the regular Republicans would be quite comfortable with, and was in fact selected to be Trump's Vice-President for exactly that reason. Third, Mueller's report is supposed to be coming out soon. I expect Mueller will have found nothing to indicate that the Russian collusion story has any substance. The report will, however, provide fodder for endless investigations by Congressional committees. There is a difference of opinion over whether impeachment is a political or criminal procedure, and people usually come down one way or the other depending upon whether they want the current president impeached. I think we will find that this year, majority opinion in Congress will be that just about anything "rises to the level of impeachment." They will not need any actual prosecutable criminal offense, or something that can plausibly be identified as "high crimes and misdemeanors" to vote for articles of impeachment. It will be enough to impeach Trump because they consider him to be a bad person. The Democrats will be able to produce ample evidence that Trump is a bad person, and it is possible that by that time, there will be no one left willing to come to the defense of Donald Trump. Two things that may happen that would send matters in a different direction: 1) Trump allows another government shutdown after the current stopgap expires, declares an emergency, and builds the wall. 2) Mueller, or someone else, finds an actual legal violation by Trump, in which case public and political opinion generally agree that he should be removed from office. Note that in case #1 above, Trump's declaration of an emergency may itself trigger impeachment. In both cases, we wind up with President Pence.

I'm going to lob out a guess based on gut feel. I've been following this story in the news fairly closely, but admit that there's nothing predictable about the path DJT has followed these past 3+ years. When he was a (fringe?) candidate, every new news cycle brought a new reason to write him off. When he was selected candidate, it was the same thing, except ramped up to another level of strangeness. Each time I got together with news junky buddies to kick this around, it was obvious to all of us that the recent news, situation X or Y, meant for sure he was either out, or at the very least there was no hope in hell he'd be elected. 
But then something happened, during the campaign, when I started to see him in a different light, believing he might win. That didn't go over well with my wife or friends, but, well, it was what it was and he did.
And then he won, and the real controversies started, ramping up the craziness and the "he's done for" talk all the way past 11.... And STILL he's in the White House, betraying all expectations, defying logic.
Part of me thinks he's indestructible, and no matter what happens next, he will survive it. He has demonstrated a clear capacity for survival. And yet, the wagons are circling, the rope looks to be lowering near his neck. I feel like he MAY accidentally stick his neck in the noose.
This ought to be a slam dunk (if we believe everything in the news, which is not a given), or at the least, very probable (if we believe half the news, which feels about reasonable), but there's a certain je ne sais quoi about him, so I'm landing firmly with one foot on the fence, and I give this 25% odds, halfway between impossible and 50-50... :-)

A) as a symbolic gesture;
-- OR -- 
B) with the expectation that the Senate would pass it. A) Requires: 
1) proof of criminal behavior that independent and suburban women Republicans would consider serious enough to justify impeachment => 40%

- http://www.historyplace.com/unitedstates/impeachments/nixon.htm
- http://www.historyplace.com/unitedstates/impeachments/clinton.htm For this question to be resolved as "Yes", the House only has to get to step 5 below, which is doable within the specific end date. However, I think getting through the first 4 steps will be a political quagmire with the general election less then 2 years away. Modern Impeachment Procedure: - http://www.historyplace.com/unitedstates/impeachments/
1) Impeachment resolutions made by members of the House of Representatives are turned over to the House Judiciary Committee which decides whether the resolution and its allegations of wrongdoing by the President merits a referral to the full House for a vote on launching a formal impeachment inquiry.
2) The entire House of Representatives votes for or against a formal impeachment inquiry, needing only a simple majority (a single vote) for approval.
3) If approved, the House Judiciary Committee conducts an investigation to determine (similar to a grand jury) if there is enough evidence to warrant articles of impeachment (indictments) against the President. The Committee then drafts articles of impeachment pertaining to specific charges supported by the evidence. The Committee votes on each article of impeachment, deciding whether to refer each article to the full House for a vote.
4) If the House Judiciary Committee refers one or more articles of impeachment, the entire House of Representatives votes on whether the article(s) merit a trial in the Senate, needing only a simple majority for approval.
5) If the full House approves at least one article of impeachment, the President is technically impeached and the matter is referred to the U.S. Senate. The House then appoints members of Congress to act as managers (prosecutors).
6) The trial of the President is held in the Senate with the Chief Justice of the U.S. Supreme Court presiding. The President can be represented by anyone he chooses. He may appear personally or leave his defense in the hands of his lawyer.
7) The entire Senate may conduct the trial or it or it may be delegated to a special committee which would report all the evidence to the full Senate.
8) The actual trial is conducted in a courtroom-like proceeding including examination and cross-examination of witnesses. During questioning, Senators remain silent, directing all questions in writing to the Chief Justice.
9) After hearing all of the evidence and closing arguments, the Senate deliberates behind closed doors then votes in open session on whether to convict or acquit the President. The vote to convict must be by a two thirds majority, or 67 Senators. If this occurs, the President is removed from office and is succeeded by the Vice President. The Senate's verdict is final and there is no right of appeal.

As things currently stand, a vote to impeach by the House would go nowhere in the Senate (even if there were irrefutable evidence of gross wrongdoing), so we have to consider under what circumstances:
     A) Democrats in the House pass it knowing it was just a symbolic vote.

2) no significant increase in Trump's popularity for external reasons (e.g. war, terrorist attack; an unlikeable Democratic presidential candidate). So far Trump's popularity has been remarkably stable (even with the recent dip) => 80% 
3) a belief among 20+ Trump-district Democrats that voting for impeachment in 2019 will help more than hurt their 2020 re-election efforts => **25% (from 50% based on the idea that most will prefer to fly below the radar on divisive issues in the lead-up to an election season.)
4) belief among Democratic leadership it would help the party overall in the 2020 elections => 90% if all of the above is true, then this seems likely.
5) Trump could resign (and get a pardon from Pence) prior to the impeachment vote being completed. => 50%
**Those multiply out to around 3.5% **Without getting too in the weeds on an a I'll call the probability of B happening 1%. It comes down to this: Trump would need to be so politically toxic to their re-election campaigns that staunch Republicans would be willing to go to war with the Trump wing of the Party. => very unlikely. An analysis like the one above comes up with less than 1% probability.  **Combined ~4.5% => I'll round it up to 5% because closer to consensus is less risky from a scoring standpoint.

I guess this can happen in one of two ways: (1) Democrats impeach because they expect the Senate to convict; or
(2) Democrats impeach not expecting the Senate to convict. There's not a lot of data points for impeachment, but it seems to me that if a president from one party gets impeached, then almost surely a president from the other party will be elected next time; which strongly motivates Senate Rs to not impeach. So the only way I see (1) happening is if Mueller probe finds something that seems very bad to lots of the public, including Rs. That's different than something simply being bad; it must also be relatively easy to understand. I am not keeping up with the investigation but the things I've heard (deals to build buildings in Moscow?) either don't seem THAT bad, or if they are bad, it's not so easy to understand why. According to 538 [1] the latest reveals, whatever they are, haven't swung public opinion much. Moreover, I conjecture that to get together enough evidence of worse things takes longer; i.e. if I did a really bad thing X, there are other things A,B,C,... which are not as bad as X, and which I can claim I did instead of X, consistently with small amounts of evidence. E.g. you find some evidence E and accuse me of X, and I say I did A instead. To tell A from X you have to gather more evidence E', but then I say I did B; etc. So if Mueller was going to come out with something seriously bad that he knew might lead to impeachment, he would try to make it ironclad. That lowers the chances even further; there has to exist something really bad; Mueller needs to find it; and he needs to get it together quickly. Let's call it a 10% chance. For (2), assume there do not surface reasons to impeach that convince a large swath of the public. What is the political calculus? In that case I feel like Rs and independents would disapprove of efforts to impeach. It would be maybe a symbolic gesture from Ds, but it would hurt them with independents, which they need. You could argue that by NOT impeaching, Ds would alienate their own base, perhaps lowering turnout; but it seems easier to convince D base of decision not to impeach --- "Senate Rs wouldn't let it happen" --- than it would be to convice Rs + Is of decision to impeach. Moreover, if Ds were going to impeach for some symbolic purpose, it would make more sense to do it closer to the 2020 election, making Oct 2019 too soon. So I want to call this possibility 10% as well. Total: 20%. [1] https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/trump-approval-ratings/

3) a belief among Trump-district Democrats that voting for impeachment in 2019 will help more than hurt their 2020 re-election efforts 
4) belief among Democratic leadership it would help the party overall in the 2020 elections Updating my probabilities:

If there will be impeachment it will be the result of most Democratic lawmakers supporting that direction. That requires that they believe it will help them in 2020, which means that ALL of the following conditions must be true: 
1) proof (understandable to a typical independent voter) of criminal wrongdoing by Trump

3) no significant increase in Trump's popularity for other reasons (e.g. war, terrorist attack; an unlikeable Democratic presidential candidate) 
4) a belief among Democrats in red states that voting for impeachment will help more than hurt their 2020 re-election efforts 
5) support among Democratic leadership My estimates of probabilities are:

2) 40%: so far they aren't things that average independents care about. It needs to be something that feels REALLY wrong to a typical independent voter.

My notes: A vote may be brought by any member and a simple majority is required to pass it, so the support of the Democratic leadership and almost all members (including some up for re-election in Trump-supporting areas) would be required. Currently neither of those conditions are met. So the question is: what is probability that a new chain of events could occur to cause that change?  Assumptions: 
1) Trump isn't likely to lose the support of his base.
2) Significant numbers of Republican lawmakers are not going to defect even in the event of conclusive evidence of serious criminal wrongdoing So: if there will be impeachment it will be the result of virtually all Democratic lawmakers, and their leadership, supporting that direction. That, in turn, requires that they believe it will help them in 2020, which means that ALL of the following conditions must be true:  
1) proof (understandable to a typical independent voter) of criminal wrongdoing by Trump
2) AND ... for a crime that a typical independent voter would consider serious
3) AND no significant increase in Trump's popularity for other reasons (e.g. war, terrorist attack; an unlikeable Democratic presidential candidate) 
4) AND a belief among Democrats in red states that voting for impeachment will help more than hurt their 2020 re-election efforts
5) AND support among Democratic leadership I assume that ALL of the above pre-conditions must be met in order for an impeachment vote to pass. My estimates of contingent probabilities are: 
1) 90-100%: there's so much smoke there must be fire
2) 40-50%: the question is, will it be something that feels REALLY wrong to a typical independent voter. (Democrats will think it's yugely serious. The question is whether independents will agree.) 
3) 85%: How to estimate the odds of something going sideways in the next two years? In the last 20 we've had 1 major terrorist attack in the US and 2 wars. Call that 15%. 
4) 15%: This is the hardest part IMO. Assume a slowdown in the economy will dent Trump. Trade conflict. The bigger issue is that if Trump is removed then Pence will take his place and that will add risk and uncertainty to local elections that is unfavorable and risky to Democrats in red states in the 2020 elections.
5) 90%: if all of the above is true, then leadership support is likely, still it's possible that leadership may feel Trump is more use wounded than dead.  OK, so those number multiply out to ~4.8% All of that is going to need to play out by October 2019. At that point we'll be less than a year ahead of a presidential election and everyone on both sides will be incented to wait it out.  My subjective impression is that there is probably too much long tail on the "yes, impeach him" end of the spectrum and the wisdom of the crowd is probably erring on the high side. Interesting op-ed by Elizabeth Drew, a Washington columnist who has been around forever and is regarded as a sage by her media peers. Whether she is particularly sagacious or not, I don't know; but it's a pretty safe bet that she does represent conventional opinion - or what will become conventional opinion - in Washington. Here's the headline and subheadline: "The Inevitability of Impeachment
Even Republicans may be deciding that the president has become too great a burden to their party or too great a danger to the country." Link: https://www.nytimes.com/2018/12/27/opinion/trump-impeachment-resign-drew.html She doesn't give a time frame, so she may not mean that the Articles of Impeachment will be passed this year, but it's difficult (for me, anyway) to imagine an impeachment vote taking place during primary season 2020. So it's 2019 or not at all. She may of course be wrong, but since she is so highly regarded her opinion is worth considering. It seems to me the key to her opinion is when she writes: "I don’t share the conventional view that if Mr. Trump is impeached by the House, the Republican-dominated Senate would never muster the necessary 67 votes to convict him... It always seemed to me that Mr. Trump’s turbulent presidency was unsustainable and that key Republicans would eventually decide that he had become too great a burden to the party or too great a danger to the country. That time may have arrived. In the end the Republicans will opt for their own political survival... Facing an assortment of unpalatable possibilities, including being indicted after he leaves office, Mr. Trump will be looking for a way out... Mr. Trump could well exhibit a similar instinct for self-preservation... like Mr. Nixon, Mr. Trump will want future legal protection. While Mr. Trump’s case is more complex than Mr. Nixon’s, the evident dangers of keeping an out-of-control president in office might well impel politicians in both parties, not without controversy, to want to make a deal to get him out of there." The flaw in this scenario is the anticipation of the Republicans in the Senate behaving in 2019 or 2020 the way they behaved in 1974. Drew seems to think that Trump is a one-off phenomenon, rather than just one example of how drastically the political climate in the U.S. has changed overall in the past twenty or so years. Trump's presidency may be turbulent, but for the Republicans, a Democratic ascendancy would be no less turbulent, and all items on the Republican agenda would be compromised, perhaps for good.  And to suggest that Republicans would abandon Trump, and hand a victory to the Democrats, over the Khashoggi murder, the Syria pullout, the Mattis resignation, or all three together is delusional.  Trump will be in no danger of conviction so will not be talked into resigning. But if enough Democrats think they can replay 1974 with Republican cooperation, Trump may well be impeached.

This doesn’t seem to be a priority for Democrats. It has little instrumental value: it won’t lead to conviction, as Republicans control the Senate. It is only valuable to House members to the extent that it sends a signal to their constituents that their representative is willing to stand up to Trump. Assuming the Mueller report does not come out with anything too damnig, it probably won’t be worth it for many House democrats. It risks alienating voters in the middle and enraging Trump supporters (leading to stronger turnout in 2020). The repercussions could mean that Democrats lose further ground in key battlegrounds like the rust belt, rural America, the South, which I don’t think they want to do.  A more progressive and constructive strategy for Democrats would be to show what they stand for, not what they stand against. To be proactive rather than reactive. I don't think there is a viable scenario where there is any move in the direction of impeachment before the Mueller investigation is wrapped up. I think there is a 80% chance that the Mueller investigation will be done in time so that there is enough time for impeachment before 1 October 2019. I see a 60% chance that there is something in the report that is impeachment-proceeding worthy and that that information gets to the relevant people. However, the probability that impeachment will actually result from this I see reduced by an unlikely (5% probability) scenario where the report is so devastating that the president will resign and a much more likely (55% probability) scenario where not starting the impeachment process is seen as the politically more advantageous alternative. So overall, I arrive at 0.8*0.6*(1-0.05-0.55)=19%.

I started with the premise that delivering at least one article of impeachment (in other words, the House of Representatives voting by a majority that the President has engaged in a high crime or misdemeanor worthy of trial in the Senate) is an extraordinary event limited to only the most egregious circumstances. Only 2 presidents have been impeached, Andrew Johnson and Bill Clinton, and a third, Richard Nixon, was almost certainly going to be impeached had he not resigned. I thus started with the premise that only 3 out of 45 presidents have been impeached or were close enough that it should count. Thus the probability of any president being impeached is 3/45 or 6.67%. However, since World War II (my definition of the modern era) 2 of 13 presidents (15%) have been impeached or nearly certainly impeached. While the sample size is small, the percentages do reflect the general reluctance to use the impeachment process, except under the most extreme political circumstances, and, at least to date, in reaction to presidential actions (ostensibly criminal) that took place while in office. While there may be more of a willingness in the modern era to utilize the impeachment process against a president, it is still low probability. I thus started with a blended probability of 11%. In addition, there have been many presidents who have been accused of impeachable committing crimes and have had opposing party members submit impeachment resolutions against them. In the modern era, that’s 7 presidents, with 2 impeachments/close enough to call it impeachment. That’s still only 28%. I assumed that, to the extent there is at least some evidence of wrongdoing and the opposing party is in power in the House, the odds of impeachment for that subset of presidents is even higher, but will largely depend on the nature of the alleged wrongdoing. Let’s call it 30-50%. I next compared this case to the 2 modern instances of impeachment/near impeachment—Nixon and Clinton. In the Nixon matter, notably at the time of the Judiciary Committee vote, a Harris poll revealed that 53% of Americans thought Nixon should be impeached. The Judiciary Committee had held public hearings over several months and based on a deep investigation performed by its counsel after the Watergate grand jury and referred the matter to it, since it was the view at the time (and generally still is the DOJ’s position) that a sitting president couldn’t be indicted.  In Clinton matter, on the other hand, the Judiciary Committee held perfunctory hearings and instead relied on Independent Counsel Ken Starr’s investigative report as the basis for the underlying determination that the president had committed crimes subject to impeachment. In both instances, the opposing party controlled the House, and in each some of the president’s own party members voted for impeachment.  Here, new House leadership under the Democrats has indicated that impeachment will not be a priority. This makes sense for now, because the House had neither held robust (in the view of the Democrats) hearings nor has it yet to receive any report or other information regarding the investigation of Special Counsel Robert Mueller. In addition, the latest polls show only about a 43% support for impeachment. The House will therefore likely begin investigations of the president and seek documents and information. Not only will these hearings be potentially politically damaging to the president, but to the extent he refuses to cooperate and produce requested documents/information, it also sets up the possibility of an impeachment charge of Obstruction of Congress. They can begin this soon while awaiting the Mueller report. Most media reporting seems to assume the Muller report will be issued soon, with speculation being sometime during the first quarter of 2019. However, the media have consistently gotten the timing wrong and have created unreasonable expectations about what Mueller might reveal in interim filings made with the court. However, given the length of time the investigation has been outstanding, it is not unreasonable to assume some kind of final report/wrap up delivered to the Justice Department by mid-2019. The question will then be what, if any, of that information will be shared with the Congress and the American public.  As a result, impeachment articles are not likely to be presented in the first six months of 2019. On the other hand, Mueller might have a bombshell that drives more immediate action, but given the length of the investigation and nature of the charges to date, it seems like anything against Trump will be either about where we are now in what we know or will take longer to release, as Mueller will need to deal with more inner circle people first. So I give that no more than a 10% chance, accounting for something completely unexpected out of Mueller and before hearings are completed in the House.  That only gives Democrats 2 summer months and September. Moreover, the longer the process is drawn out, there is an argument that the Democrats benefit from it remaining in the public eye, with Republicans uncomfortably dancing around the issue, defending a president they don’t necessarily like but viewing the alternative as disastrous for the 2020 election. (Counterintuitively, some Republicans might hope for impeachment only so that Pence could come in to steady the ship until a better Republican candidate comes along in 2020 to save the party from political ruin. But given the extreme remedy, most Republicans will need strong evidence of real (in their view) crimes beyond campaign finance issues.) The sum of this is likely a drawn out process with move and countermove as the impeachment process slowly progresses over a number of months, adding pressure to the president and Republican party, leading into the 2020 primary. While some Democratic members of the House (particularly those with more progressive bases) may submit impeachment resolutions early on, those will likely get referred to the Judiciary Committee to allow the process to be drawn out for its political benefit.  In addition, impeachment brings both political uncertainty and, potentially, political turmoil. Working on the assumption that most politicians do genuinely care about those things (I’m not a cynic), leadership of both parties recognize that impeachment really must only be used in the most egregious of circumstances. Democratic leaders such as Nancy Pelosi certainly recognize this and remember the fallout against both parties during the Clinton impeachment. Unless the Democratic leadership loses control of the issue to a maverick contingency in the House (or if polls overwhelmingly support impeachment—both of which seem unlikely) it appears more probable, that while the Democrats will continue to keep the issue in the spotlight and perhaps even encourage some in the party to demand impeachment, any such process will last throughout most of 2019 and at least until the primaries in 2020. Given these political realities, impeachment, if at all, would likely occur later than October 2019. On the other hand, I’ll allow some wiggle room for anything really damning coming out of Mueller’s investigation. In addition, as information comes out from the investigation and hearings, the public’s appetite for impeachment could increase to a point where Democrats are emboldened. They might see this no longer as an issue to be drawn out, but as a chance to take the high road and remove a president seen as harmful to the nation. If so, the summer would be the best time, as the 2020 election gears up with candidates vying for positions for the upcoming primaries and those supportive of an early and successful impeachment could point to their leadership in the process. While I don’t think this is likely, it is an uncertainty that should be accounted for, particularly given we don’t yet know what we will learn from the Mueller investigation. As a result, I put the chances of impeachment during the 3rd quarter higher than they would be during the first 6 months, but still only at about 25%. In light of an original chance of around 40% (I averaged the 30-50% range), this leads me to think the overall chance is no more than 14%.(40*.1)+(40*.25).

With the current composition of the Senate, a conviction seems *very* unlikely, which suggests that House passing such articles would be (mostly) futile. Still, Dems in the House might perceive some political benefit from impeaching Trump, even if conviction is unlikely. This is why I forecast a non-zero (though small) probability of impeachment.

If this were a legal proceeding rather than the political process it is intended to be, there would be have been an impeachment months ago.  In January there will be enough Ds to pass an impeachment article in the House, but not nearly enough of any flavour in the Senate to convict. Impeachment is an entirely political process. There are a number of reasons Democrats could use to impeach Trump, including: a) The Emoluments clause; b) alleged cooperation with Russian and; c) campaign finance violations. Importantly, Democrats don't need proof of any actual wrongdoing to proceed with impeachment and, arguably, Bill Clinton was impeached for lesser perceived impropriety.  My original estimate is that there is roughly a 1/3rd chance that Democrats will decide that the political calculus favors impeachment. John Edwards was indicted in a criminal court for similar campaign finance violations (i.e. paying off a mistress) and was acquitted. While I wouldn't completely exclude an impeachment vote in the House--and the baseline rate for impeachment following a serious investigation of the President's behavior is high - the deadline is too soon. Arguments: 1) Mueller's investigation could go on for many more months. Available information suggests he may be close to forming a view about what happened in the 2015-16 campaign, but that still leaves the post-election period and the obstruction of justice issue in February-May 2017. Trump has refused to answer questions about these two issues, but I doubt Mueller will just accept that. Moreover, Trump is under pressure from McConnell to nominate a permanent AG, and I think Mueller will wait for that to increase the perceived legitimacy of his report. So Mueller's report will be ready, I expect, no earlier that April-June 2019. This leaves little time for discussions and decisions before the deadline of this question. 2) What will Mueller's report contain when it is ready? Anything less than a clear smoking gun will likely lead to months of extensive discussions among the Democrats how to react. Again, the deadline is too soon.  3) An intriguing possibility is that Mueller will report that Trump lied under oath about certain issues. Trump's lawyers were consulting extensively with Manafort's lawyers under their joint defense agreement, and now we know that Mueller thinks Manafort lied (I suppose he can prove it). So if the Manafort and Trump answers were coordinated, Trump may be exposed. However, even this may not be quite the smoking gun the Democrats need, as Trump's answers were "to the best of his recollection", and the inaccurate answers may pertain to relatively minor events. (This is different from Bill Clinton's impeachment (for lying under oath), because there the lying was about issues central to the investigation.) So this brings us back to point 2) above. 4) Finally, even if Mueller does find a clear smoking gun of an impeachable offense, the Democrats would still want to attract at least some Republican votes in the House, to prevent the whole exercise being seen as a purely partisan affair. This again will take a few months to negotiate.  5) Can Trump be impeached for non-Mueller-related offenses? The Dems will start a few investigations - on his receiving money from foreign governments,  etc. Careful investigations will take many months, so no definite result before Oct 1. Besides, the Dems would likely plan these investigations to finish in 2020, in time for the presidential elections.

It takes 218 members of the House of Representatives to impeach. The Democrats have 235 seats for the 116 Congress.  So, it's possible. The question is why would they? There's a lot of speculation,  such as this article in the Washington Post, that identifies Trump as an individual of interest, i.e. "Individual 1", in a criminal investigation.[1] But, at this point, no one outside of the Mueller investigation knows what they have - but there are an awful lot of indictments, many with uncharged individuals.  How much time does impeachment take? The articles of impeachment against Bill Clinton occurred during the lame duck session, just what we have going on now, and little real investigation. It took a month. Nixon, on the other hand, took six months to report back articles of impeachment to the House.  So, the questions are, at this point: 
1. When will Mueller present his case? I think he is near his endgame, since Trump is being identified as a person of interest, and Trump has turned in his responses to Mueller, but Mueller probably still needs a few months.
2. How long will it take for the House to pass a resolution giving its judicial committee authority to investigate?  They won't do it before Mueller concludes his investigation, since there has already been so many phony Congressional investigations on this topic.
3. Once those two things happen, it's going to have to go through a whole process of Congressional review and partisan politics. How long does that take? I'm guessing this is going to be a lot more complicated than Watergate, which means more time. The time limit is key here. The gears of justice grind slowly, particularly when its a powerful person like the President with a lot of tools to draw out the game. I don't think that anything starts until Mueller is finished. I think Mueller is nearing his endgame. But, this environment is going to be challenging and its going to be like a reality show. It's going to take time to kick off and it's going to go on longer than we all expect, even once all the evidence is packaged, neatly presented in a bow and handed to Congress.   “This is obviously a significant plea and statement. It means that when the president was representing during the campaign that he had no business interests in Russia, that that wasn’t true,” said Rep. Adam B. Schiff (Calif.), the ranking Democrat in line to become chairman of the House Intelligence Committee. “If the president and his associates were being untruthful in real time as they were pursuing this deal, what does it mean now about how much we can rely on what the president is saying about any continuing Russian financial interest?” [1] https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/individual-1-trump-emerges-as-a-central-subject-of-mueller-probe/2018/11/29/e3968994-f3f7-11e8-80d0-f7e1948d55f4_story.html?noredirect=on
